t: There*p is an evil which I have seen under the sun, and it is*i common among men:

A man to whom God has given riches and wealth and honor, so that he lacks nothing for himself of all he desires; yet God does not give him power to eat of it, but a foreigner consumes it. This is*i vanity, and it is*i an evil affliction.

If*p a man begets a hundred children*i and lives many years, so that the days of his years are many, but his soul is not satisfied with goodness, or indeed he has no burial, I say that*i a stillborn child is*i better than he—
for it comes in vanity and departs in darkness, and its name is covered with darkness.
Though it has not seen the sun or known anything,*i this has more rest than that man,
even if he lives a thousand years twice—but has not seen goodness. Do not all go to one place?
All*pn the labor of man is*i for his mouth, And*ld yet the soul is not satisfied.
For*ld what more has the wise man*i than the fool? What*ld does the poor man have, Who*ld knows how*i to walk before the living?
Better*ld is*i the sight of the eyes than the wandering of desire. This*ld also is*i vanity and grasping for the wind.
Whatever*ln one is, he has been named already, For*ld it is known that he is*i man; And*ld he cannot contend with Him who is mightier than he.
Since*ld there are many things that increase vanity, How*ld is*i man the better?
For*p who knows what is*i good for man in life, all the days of his vain life which he passes like a shadow? Who can tell a man what will happen after him under the sun?
